journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Burn-in and the performance quality measures in continuous heterogeneous populations

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Statistics, Ewha Womans University, Republic of Korea
2Department of Mathematical Statistics, University of the Free State, South Africa
3Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Ji H Cha, Department of Statistics, Ewha Womans University, 11-1 Deehyun-dong, Seodaemun-gu, Seoul 120-750, Republic of Korea. Email : jhcha@ewha.ac.kr

abstract.p: Burn-in is a method used to eliminate initial failures in field use. To burn-in a component or system means to subject it to a period of use prior to the time when it is to actually be used. Under the assumption of decreasing or bathtub-shaped population failure rate functions, various problems of determining optimal burn-in have been intensively studied in the literature. In this paper, we assume that a population is composed of stochastically ordered subpopulations, described by their own performance quality measures and study optimal burn-in, which optimizes overall performance measures. It turns out that this setting can justify burn-in even when it is not necessary in the framework of conventional approaches. For instance, it could be reasonable to perform burn-in even when the failure rate function that describes a heterogeneous population of items increases and this is one of the main and important findings of the current study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Burn-in is a method that can be used to eliminate initial failures in field usage. To burn-in a component or a system means to subject it to a period of simulated use prior to actual operation. Due to the high failure rate at the early stages of a component’s life, burn-in has been widely accepted as an effective method of screening out early failures before systems are actually used in field operation. An introduction to this important area of reliability engineering can be found in Jensen and Petersen1 and Kuo and Kuo.2

Burn-in is an important part of a production process, which can improve the quality of products with an initially decreasing failure rate. As this operation is usually costly, the financial implications should be carefully analyzed. Considering, on the one hand, the cost of burn-in and, on the other hand, the gains due to a better quality of products constitutes the problem of obtaining an optimal burn-in time. Therefore, most of the papers devoted to burn-in deal with minimization of the corresponding cost functions, see, for example, Weiss and Dishon,3 Clarotti and Spizzichino,4 Cha,5–7 Mi8–10 and Sheu and Chien.11

When the lifetime failure rate is decreasing or bathtub (BT) shaped, burn-in can be usually justified. It is worth noting that heterogeneity of a population is often the reason, why the resulting failure rate is decreasing, at least in some time intervals (and, for example, having a BT shape): see Block and Savits12 for the corresponding discussion in the burn-in framework and Finkelstein13 for some general considerations. Until now, only a few studies on burn-in have been performed for mixed (heterogeneous) populations. For example, Nguyen and Murthy14 considered a heterogeneous population described by a mixed Weibull law and obtained the optimal burn-in time that minimized the cost of products sold under warranty. We recently studied burn-in for the case of the discrete mixture that describes the population with two subpopulations (“strong” and “weak”) and reported the results in Cha and Finkelstein.15

In the current paper we consider continuous mixtures of subpopulations. It is well known that continuous mixtures constitute an effective tool for modeling the corresponding population heterogeneity. These models are important in various reliability engineering applications. In practice, heterogeneous items with different reliability (and quality) characteristics may be produced due to, for example, defective resources and components, human error, an unstable production environment and other causes of random effects. Numerous publications on modeling continuous heterogeneity can be found in the literature (see, for example, Finkelstein16 and references therein). For instance, in Finkelstein17 the results from a life test of 750 miniature light bulbs were described and it was verified that the population distribution for the light bulbs could be closely modeled by the continuous gamma-mixing model with a Weibull baseline cumulative distribution function (CDF). Thus, the life test result in Finkelstein17 experimentally justifies that the gamma mixture of Weibull distributions with increasing failure rates can be a useful tool for modeling the upside-down BT shaped mixture failure rate, which is vanishing as
t → ∞
(see our Example 4, where we use the exponential mixing distribution as a specific case of the gamma distribution). In fact, the continuous gamma-mixing model is also frequently adopted in other areas of lifetime data analysis for dealing with population heterogeneity. For example, it is well known that human mortality follows the Gompertz lifetime distribution with an exponentially increasing failure (mortality) rate. However, recently it was observed that the population failure rate levels off for the oldest segment of the population exactly in accordance with the gamma-Gompertz mixture model considered in our Example 3 (human mortality plateau, as, for example, in Thatcher18).

We obtain the optimal burn-in time via minimization of the total expected cost function, which takes into account the expected costs during burn-in and the expected gain during the mission time (in field operation). It is well known that when the failure rate of a component is increasing, there is no need to perform the burn-in procedure and only the cases of decreasing failure rate and the non-monotonic failure rate (e.g. with BT shape) can constitute the possibility for burn in. This refers to the conventional settings for homogeneous populations. However, when we deal with heterogeneous populations with subpopulations described not only by their failure rates but also by different quality of performance, the situation can be dramatically different. For example, the burn-in can be justified even for increasing failure rates! The proof and illustrations of this important statement is the goal of this paper. This possibility arises from the fact that items are heterogeneous not only in failure rate but also in the corresponding quality of performance function.

For an introductory illustration of the previously described concept, consider a heterogeneous population of items with increasing population failure rate and increasing (ordered) failure rates of subpopulations. Therefore, the conventional burn-in should not be performed in this case. Let, along with the failure rate, each item be described by its quality function. It is natural to assume that a smaller failure rate also corresponds to a better (larger) quality of performance function. Let an item perform a very important mission. Suppose that the probability of a component’s failure during this mission is very small (e.g. the mission time is relatively short) and therefore, the absolute difference between probabilities of failure for subpopulations is also very small, whereas there can be a considerable difference in quality of performance (in absolute values). A poor quality might lead to a failure of a mission or a mission of poor completion and, eventually, substantial economic loss. In this situation, obviously, reliability characteristics during the mission are not so important, whereas the quality is of major concern. Therefore, although performing burn-in for some time may lead to an increase in the failure rate (which, as described, is not so important for this setting), a crucial increase in performance can be attained due to elimination of weak items. As a specific example, consider a navigation device and suppose that its mission is to provide navigational information for a launched missile as it seeks its target. In this case, the accuracy in coordinates and heading corresponds to our performance quality. As the mission time is obviously very short, the reliability characteristics during the mission are not so important compared with the impact of the accuracy of the item’s performance in the mission.

The structure of this paper is as follows. In the section ‘Ordered subpopulations and the effect of burn-in’ a general formulation of the lifetime distribution of stochastically ordered subpopulations is given and the corresponding population distribution is derived. Based on this setup, the effect of burn-in on the corresponding heterogeneous population is discussed. It is shown that the burn-in procedure improves the population quality meaning that the proportion of strong items in the population is increasing. In the section ‘Optimal burn-in time for performance quality functions’ the total expected cost function is obtained and some quantitative analysis for obtaining the optimal burn-in time is performed. In contrast to the homogeneous case, we observe that the burn-in procedure can improve the quality performance measures even when the failure rate function of the population increases. In the section ‘Examples’ two meaningful examples are considered. Finally, conclusions are drawn in the section ‘Concluding remarks.’
Throughout this paper, by increasing or decreasing, we mean non-decreasing or non-increasing, respectively, unless otherwise specified.

Thus, as is shown in these examples, burn-in in the case of a mixture of subpopulations with non-decreasing failure rates not only increases the proportion of the strong subpopulations but also may decrease the mixture failure rate (in Example 2, it initially decreases) and thus it is obviously justified from the conventional point of view. However, in the next section, we will see that burn-in may be justified even when the failure rates of subpopulations and the mixture failure rate are increasing.

sec.title: Optimal burn-in time for performance quality functions
sec.p: Now we will describe a model that already takes into consideration the costs and gains involved. This cost structure (expected costs) accounts for the performance quality after burn-in and defines gains (negative costs) proportional to the mean remaining lifetime. Other types of cost structures considered in the literature (e.g. Mi8,10) can be also discussed in a similar way. At first, as in the homogeneous case, we do not reveal the composition of our population and deal with the observed mixture distribution function. Thus, in accordance with this model

As was stated in the Introduction, the burn-in modeling was mainly focused only on lifetimes and did not pay attention to the performance quality of components. However, when the performance quality is also taken into account, burn-in can be justified in cases when it was not previously relevant. In Appendix 2 we present real data used as a motivating example for the performance quality of components.20 The data illustrates the fact that in many practical situations, not only the lifetime of the item itself but also the performance quality can be an important factor, which provides a strong motivation for introducing performance quality measures into the study of burn-in. There are other similar examples for quality performance measures of items: the error rate of semiconductor devices, the malfunctioning rate of electronic devices, the accuracy of measuring devices such as gyroscope, etc. (see also the Introduction).

In accordance with this reasoning, assume now that a component from our heterogeneous population is characterized by the quality (the gain for the unit of time during the mission time)

sec.title: Examples
sec.p:
It is tempting to use the setting of Example 1 for the simplest illustration, but the mixture MRL in this case is non-finite. Indeed, the mixture failure rate, as follows from Example 1, (when
t → ∞
) tends to the failure rate of the Pareto distribution of the form
1 −
t
− 1
, which does not have a finite first moment. Other cost structures (defined, for example, by gains during the fixed interval of mission time) can be considered in this case.

First, we will describe a meaningful example where the subpopulations’ failure rates and the mixture failure rate are increasing and therefore, the conventional burn-in should not be performed, whereas considering the quality of performance function changes the situation and justifies the necessity of burn-in.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: Most papers dealing with optimal burn-in procedures consider homogeneous populations of items. The starting point is usually an assumption on the shape of the corresponding failure rate function, e.g. the BT-shaped failure rate, the eventually increasing failure rate, etc. In this paper, on the contrary, we considered the heterogeneous population modeled by the continuous mixture that can have different shapes of the population failure rate function. This can be seen as a more realistic and practical setting.

Furthermore, we studied the optimal burn-in time for maximizing the quality of performance characteristics of burned-in items, which has not been previously considered in the literature. Traditionally, burn-in is applied to items with an initially decreasing failure rate. However, we showed in this study (under the main assumption that the quality of performance of items in subpopulations are also ordered), that the optimal burn-in time can exist even if the mixture failure rate function is increasing. Taking into account the importance of burn-in procedures in practice, it is hard to overestimate the importance of the result obtained in this paper.

It is interesting to note that when applying time-varying stresses (as in accelerated trials; see, Bagdonavicius and Nikulin21) the increasing failure rate can also result from the initial decreasing failure rate. In this paper we did not discuss testing of the considered models and the corresponding inferential problems. Relevant references for these topics are Jensen and Petersen1 and Kececioglu and Sun.22

app.title: Appendix 2
app.p: A life test was conducted on items related to electronic packaging (for the solder/Cu pad interface data) and degradation testing was conducted on these devices for the light intensity degradation data. The test data are taken from Huang and Askin11 and are listed in Tables 1 and 2. Both sets of data are for the same environment stresses. The degradation data presents the percentage of light intensity reduction compared to the original measurement of each test unit. In field operation, the device is discarded if the light intensity drops to 60% of its original value. This data illustrates that, in many practical situations, not only the lifetime of the item itself, but also the performance quality can be an important factor, which provides a strong motivation for introducing performance quality measures in the study of burn-in.

caption.p: Solder/Cu pad interface fatigue lifetime data.
Light intensity degradation data (in percentage relative to the original measurement).

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the reviewers for helpful comments which significantly improved the presentation of this paper.

The work of the second author was supported by the National Research Foundation of South Africa under grant FA2006040700002.
